columns.text: In this problem, we will discuss the concept behind the Rule of 72 in estimating the period it takes for an amount to double.

Using a rate of $10\%$, we can show using this estimation that the time it takes for an investment to double is $7.2$ years. 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Time}&=\dfrac{72}{10\%}\\[15 pt]
&=7.2
\end{aligned}$$

Substituting the values, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Future value}&=\$1 \times (1+0.10)^{7.3}\\
&=\$2.005
\end{aligned}$$

If we use the Rule of 73, then the future value is indeed $\$2$ which is double the initial value.

To solve for the rate at which the Rule of 72 is accurate, we can simply use the same formula above with the unknown being the rate.

$$\begin{aligned}
\$2&=\$1\times(1+\text{Rate})^{7.2}\\[15 pt]
\text{Rate}&=0.10106
\end{aligned}$$

This means that the Rule of 72 is accurate at a rate of $10.11\%$
